titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. Morning visits from Mr Woodward, Mr Ecky and Mr Fisher— I dined with Mr Andrew Severin, and after dinner, looked at some of his Collection of medals and Coins. It is a very large and costly collection, but not sufficiently arranged in order to be viewed with advantage— Of many hundreds it was impossible to look at more than fifty or sixty with attention, at one time— The most curious that I saw, were the medals on the death of Louis 16. and his Queen; of Charles 12 and Gustavus 3 of Sweden— The seven Bell Thalers of Frederick Duke of Brunswick Lunenburg; and some antient Danish Coins of Canute the Great, Margaret of Waldemar, Christiern 2 and others— His collection of Danish Coins alone, contains between three, and
four hundred pieces— The whole Collection must be of more than two thousand— There was a Mr Krug there; a German; and a Mr James, an Englishman, both of whom have also Collections— Mr Krug’s is confined exclusively to the Russian Coins, and we all agreed to go and look at it next Thursday morning— He had with him several of the leather Coins which were used in this Country in the 9th and 10th Centuries, before there was any Coinage of Metals, here—they are of various forms—square, triangular, round, and irregular; with various stamps upon them on one side, in the centre— They are about the thickness and hardness of sole-leather; all but one of smaller dimensions than an American dollar, and that not much larger— Mr Krug said they were so rare that it was impossible to say with certainty whether they were genuine or Counterfeit.— Came from Mr Severin’s, immediately home.

2. Morning visits from Mr Montreal and Mr Harris— A Gentleman who came as a Courier from Abo, brought me a packet from Mr: Speyer, at Stockholm, enclosing one from Mr Russell in London— Two Sailors came to me, who had belonged to two of the vessels which came last Summer under false American Colours and have been seized by the Government here. It appears that the vessels all excepting one are to be restored as English property, to their real owners— The Captains want to ship men again, and one of these Sailors who is unwilling to ship again in a vessel which he now knows to be no American complained that he was threatened with being turned out of his lodgings, if he refused to ship with some of these Impostors— Mr Harris came in while they were here; and thought this man turbulent and unreasonable— I walked before dinner, stopp’d at the bookseller Howert’s and purchased a book, which I had promised to give Charles— After dinner I called at Mr Bentzon’s lodgings, with letters which I wished him to take, but he was not at home. I also called upon Count Löwenhielm, Mr Brandel, and Mr Saltus; who were however all abroad. I walked an hour afterwards on the Quays— Closed the Evening with Cards; untill the Cannon from the fortress announced the midnight Mass of Easter-Eve. Although fine, the weather was cold and deterred me from giving the whole Night to a sight of these Ceremonies.

3. Easter Sunday, by the Old Style or Greek Calendar— Easter day by the Roman Calendar was on the 29th: of March— The full Moon of March was on the 16/28 and accordingly before the 21st: Old Style, and after the 21st: New Style— The Greek Church therefore waited for the April full moon which was on the 14/26 last Sunday— The Sunday after the full moon next succeeding the 21st: of March is the Easter day according to both Churches— I went with Mr Smith to the Maltese Roman Catholic Chapel, and heard the Mass performed by the Bishop of Minsk or Wilna— The Chapel is small, containing not more than 200 persons— The music was very good— I met there among others the Chevalier Brancia with whom after the Ceremony was over I walked, and had much conversation. After returning home, I found Mr Fisher here on a visit— Also Madame Colombi and her Sister— I took a long second walk after dinner, and read the Sermons 9. and 10. Vol. 6. of the English Preacher— On Living peaceably with all men; and on public Spirit— Read also a few pages of Watts’s Logic; a book which I read in 1785 and 1786. when at Haverhill, preparing for College, and which I have never looked into since— As the only formal Treatise upon Logic that I ever read, it gave me the first Notions of an important Art, but in the pages that I read this day, there is nothing of which a single trace of recollection dwelt upon my Mind. I closed this Evening very early; for the purpose of having a long morning to-morrow.

4. Second Easter-Holiday, and the Empresses held a Court at the Winter Palace, where I attended with Mr Smith at one O’Clock P.M. It was very short, thinly attended, and dull: The Chevalier de Bray asked me to go and dine with him, which I accepted— After returning from Court I went with Charles and saw one of the Shows on the Isaac Square— It was a slight of hand man— Dined with the Chevalier de Bray— General Watzdorf, the Saxon Minister was there— He has a leave of absence, and goes the day after to-morrow. He has already sent Cards to take leave, and Count Bose has sent his as Chargé d’Affairs of Saxony— There was also an Italian musician named Dedicati, director of the music at the Maltese chapel— After dinner he performed on the Piano, and Madame de Bray sung— Several beautiful compositions of Paesiello and Guglielmi— Count St: Julien paid an Evening visit there— I called at the Ambassadors and the Chevalier de Bray’s— Neither of them at home— Walked an hour and on my return home found Madame Bezerra, and Captain Boit, as visitors— Mr Bezerra afterwards came in and they stayed untill Midnight— Mr and Madame Rayneval, Captain Guedes, and Mr Harris had also been on visits, but were gone— My project of making short Evenings I am afraid is impracticable.

5. Morning visit from Mr Montreal. I went with Charles to see one of the Gachellies— It was the Arabian fire, and the piece of Old Clock work, we had seen upon the river, on the holidays of the Carnaval— We found it too cold and windy for walking— After dinner I took my long walk round the Fontanka and river Quay— The Ladies went to Madame Bezerra’s— I spent the rest of the Evening with Charles; and find myself again with a sharp Cold.

6— We were invited by the widow of Mr Schenbom, late Chargé d’Affairs of Sweden to attend his funeral this morning at ten O’Clock— Mr Smith was specially invited to attend as a bearer. The funeral service was performed at the Swedish Church which was filled with people— There was a short discourse by the Clergyman, in the Swedish language, two or three psalms or hymns sung accompanied with the organ; and a short prayer by the Pastor at the Coffin— The formality of strewing dust upon the Coffin was observed— The Bearers were Messrs: Rayneval, Lebzeltern, Smith, Krabbe, Brancia, Jouffroy, Count Bose and Count Jenison, all young, and all but Rayneval unmarried men; but all Chargés d’Affairs or Secretaries of Legation— Mr Schenbom was married, and died at the age of 68— Count Löwenhjelm and Mr Brandel acted as Marshals— Counts St: Julien, Bussche & Frohberg, and the Chevalier Bezerra were the Ministers present— The burial was without the City, but the Carriages followed in procession only as far as the Fontanka Canal— About one O’Clock we returned home— I went with Charles before dinner to the Gachellies, two of which we visited— The Chinese Shadows, and an Automaton Rope-dancer— The last I had not seen before, and it is not more worth seeing than the rest— Mrs Adams and Catherine spent the Evening at Madame Colombi’s— We had a fall of snow this morning while we were at Church.

7. I called this morning upon Mr Andrew Severin according to an appointment with him to go and see Mr Krug’s Collection of Russian Coins— But Mr Krug resides on the Wasili-Ostroff, and there being now no Bridge upon the river, the wind high, and a flight of hail and snow just as I called on Mr Severin, he thought it would be best to postpone our visit to Mr Krug to another day; of which he promised to give me notice— I went before dinner with Charles to the Gachellies, and saw two of the Exhibitions on the Statue Square. The first were feats of horsemanship, and tumbling— The second tumblers and Rope-dancers the same we had seen upon the River, and I think also last year at Easter— It was past six O’Clock when we came home. I walked again in the Evening, and after my return home gave a lesson to Charles. I find his deficiency of English pronunciation so great that it gives me some concern— In my own ardor to teach him French, I had neglected his English, trusting that it would come of itself hereafter, while the opportunity for him to learn french may be short, and ought not to be lost— But he now speaks French so much more easily than English, that he talks it by preference with every body, and his organs are so unused to the harsh utterance of English sounds that he finds it very difficult to articulate them

8. Mr Nancarro called upon me this morning, and took the dispatches and letters that I had ready for America. He is going in two or three days to Reval, where he has a vessel to sail for Baltimore as soon as the gulph will be clear of ice. I went with Charles to the Gachellies, and saw the Puppet-show— There is now left for us only one more to visit. Mr Smith dined abroad— Dr Galloway was here after dinner to visit our Cook Quinzard, who is very ill— Count Maistre came to take leave of us, and told me that he was going to Poltosk in White Russia, to meet a Lady avec qui (said he) je dois vivre à ce qu’on dit— I asked him if he expected soon to return; but he spoke of it with some uncertainty; whether indeed he should return at all— He said that he was going to find himself in a situation somewhat singular; to meet a daughter; a young Lady of 17 whom he had never yet seen— He meant the daughter of the Lady he was going to marry— The Ladies were out in the procession of Carriages round the Square.

9. Morning visit from Mr Woodward, who has received at length information that Mr Gray’s ship Rubicon Captain Hovey, had put into Lisbon in distress— She sailed from Cronstadt last September, and from Gothenburg in October, since which she had not before been heard of. I went with Charles to the Gachellies, and saw Chiarini’s amphitheatre and the feats of horsemanship— This was the last of all the Exhibitions upon the Square this Season— After dinner I walked again upon the Boulevard in front of the Admiralty— The procession of Carriages was numerous; but the weather continues as it has been the whole week, cold and comfortless, with two or three flights of snow, one of which lasted more than an hour— I met and walked with Mr Saltus, who told me he had a vessel which would sail by this day three weeks from Cronstadt, and by which he offered to send my letters and dispatches— But as she is to come from Riga first it will be more than three weeks before her departure for America— I received this morning a letter from my brother.

10. The last and liveliest of the Easter-holidays— The Ladies and Children went to the procession of Carriages round the square, and I walked on the Boulevard from half-past six untill nine in the Evening— The crowd both of Carriages and of walkers, was greater than I have ever seen it, on this occasion— The weather was milder, than it had been the preceding days. The Empresses were there— I met the French Ambassador and Count Frohberg walking. Met also and walked with Mr Plummer— At 9 O’Clock, all the sports were finished and the Square was almost deserted— I read a few
Sections of Watts’s Logic, and the Sermons 11. and 12. Vol. 6. of the English Preacher— On Death, and on the rewards of Beneficence in the present World.

11. Morning visits from Mr Montreal, Mr Woodward, and Mr Harris— They absorbed so much of the day that I had no time left to write— I walked before and after dinner— The ice from Lake Ladoga, is passing down the river; but there is very little of it— I took Charles to walk with me, but Mrs Adams took him up in the Carriage at the Corner of the Palace— On returning home I found Mr Ingraham, who is to sail for Boston, by the first vessel that goes from Cronstadt— We finished the Evening with Cards.

12. Mr Plummer called upon me this morning with Mr Andrew, who came to take leave on his departure for Archangel— I received from Gothenburg a Packet of letters, from America, London and Hamburg— I intended to have called upon Mr Meyer, but had forgotten the Bridge was gone, and unprepared to cross the river in a Boat— Walking, I met first Mr Laval, and afterwards Mr Anderson, with whom I walked about a quarter of an hour— Dined at the French Ambassador’s— The company were about twenty-five— It was about half formal, a style of etiquette between full State and familiarity— Count Alexander Soltikoff was there— I asked Rayneval if he had the suppressed newspaper— They had not received it— Jouffroy the Prussian Chargé d’Affairs is the only person who has it and had lent it to Baron Blome, who promised to send it to me, and accordingly did in the Evening— Count Bussche next to whom I sat at table said this was the [“]Henker’s Mahlzeit”—the Hangman’s Banquet— He meant in allusion to the prospect of the War— Count St: Julien is still positive the War is impossible, because the French horses are fed upon the roofs of the houses; and he knows, having long been a General of Cavalry, that this breeds Epidemic distempers among the horses— That is, says the Count, not only your horse who has eat the thatch will die; but my horse who has not eat it, will die too, for standing along side of yours— Now I have calculated that there are in the Russian Army on the frontier about 200,000 horses—therefore there must be as many on the french side— The Country is already exhausted of forage, so that it cannot feed its own horses—how then is it possible it should feed 400,000 horses extra— Therefore Napoleon cannot begin the War before August— Therefore he will not have time for a Campaign long enough to finish the business this year— He wishes to make a short War of it— Therefore he will not begin this year— Russia will not begin at-all. Therefore there will be no War this year.— Thus much for Count St: Julien’s prophecy— I paid Evening visits at the Chevalier de Bray’s, but they were abroad— At General Betancourt’s, where we saw Madame Colombi and her Sister; and at the Chevalier Bezerra’s; his Lady was at home, and he came in while I was there; but they were going out again— The Paper sent me by Baron Blome was the Hamburg Correspondent of 22. April— It contains the trial of four persons subalterns in the War Department of France, for corrupt and treasonable communications to Russian Diplomatic Agents— It was taken from the Journal de l’Empire of 15. April— I take both these Gazettes; but the respective numbers of them containing this trial were suppressed at the Post-Office here.

13. Visit this morning from Baron Blome, with whom I had much Conversation, and who thinks the War inevitable— Blome is not liked here, and has generally little credit for talents— There is a sort of effeminacy in his manners, which savours too much of his frivolity; but he has extensive views, extreme activity in obtaining information, and good sources for obtaining much of it— My walk before dinner was short. After dinner I went with the Ladies and Charles to the Catherinan-hoff May-day procession of Carriages— It was well attended, and both the Empresses were there— I walked partly home with Charles— Cards afterwards.

14. Morning visit from Mr Harris— I walked before and after dinner in the Summer Gardens— In the morning I met and walked with the French Ambassador and had much Conversation with him— He still professes to hope that the War will not commence at present. But since the Emperor’s departure he is in a manner left here with nothing to do— He says if Nesselrode had been sent to Paris, he is sure there would have been no War this year— But I asked him whether the late trial at Paris, in which Nesselrode’s name was a little involved would not have hurt him— He said no— The matter would not have been made so public— Chernicheff was the only person who in that matter could have been peculiarly obnoxious; and it would have been enough to have ordered him away from France— The Ambassador however now speaks with some appearance of dissatisfaction of what is done here—dwells upon trifles—complains that Count Romanzoff is slow, and irresolute—talks of offensive publications in the Journal du Nord— He hinted that he had complained of them to Count Soltykoff, who had answered him by referring to the like publications offensive to Russia in the French Gazettes— Oh! you recriminate, do you? well! I despise les folliculaires too much to say any more about it— He adds that he goes into no Society— Visits no where—because he finds every body so shy of him, that he perceives his presence is irksome— He finds his situation therefore extremely insipid— I took Charles to walk with me after dinner— Found Mr Haven and Mr Plummer Evening visitors when I returned home— The weather is almost at summer heat.

15. Morning visit from Mr Montreal— Walks in the Summer-Garden before and after dinner— There is still a remnant of the Ice from the Ladoga, floating down upon the river, and the atmosphere is at Summer-heat— I saw a tree in the open air, almost in full leaf— The grass has begun to shoot up, in the Summer Garden, and is entirely green— On returning home this Evening I found Count St: Julien upon a visit. He persists in his opinion that the scarcity will prevent the War— The Count was perfectly good-humoured, and avowed his prejudices against the Class of Merchants, without reserve— He says they are the Cause of all these Wars, without ever taking part in them, or suffering from them— They fatten and grow rich upon the misery, and blood of Nations— That they have no Country, but their Counting-house— No God but Gain— That they will traffic with the Enemies of their Nation as readily as with their friends, and supply him with provisions, ammunition, arms, any thing that he wants to destroy their own Countrymen— He was a Nobleman, and it was natural he should not like Merchants— It was the Caste of Society that he esteemed and respected the least of-all— He was a military-man; and there was a natural antipathy between the soldier and the pedlar— He had ransomed some towns, and burnt some villages, in the course of his profession, but there was a reason of public necessity for it— But the merchants, burnt and destroyed by little and little—they consumed by defrauding on all sides— It was nothing to them who was victorious or who vanquished; they made their profit with equal indifference out of all— He had seen them at Vienna, after the French had been in possession of the City— To them it was as if nothing had happened— They sold their goods as freely to the frenchmen, and took the money pressed out from the Contributions of their Countrymen, as gaily as if it had been a public Jubilee— This was all said in a careless, rattling, good humoured tone, and is a sample of Austrian, or High Dutch feelings Military Arrogance—and the radical prejudices of German Nobility— The Dark side of the commercial Character does present features by no means amiable, or respectable, and the Count seized them with sufficient sagacity— But the fair side, would present others which restore the balance of comparative merit; and in the estimate of impartial Justice place the Commercial Caste, if not upon a level with the rest, at least by their side and not far beneath them— Had a sensible merchant been present, if he could not have justified his profession from the Counts reproaches, he might have turned the tables upon him, either as a Warrior, a Noble, a Courtier or a Diplomatist, all of which classes have vices of Condition, at least as odious as any that can be imputed to the merchants; and from those vices, the Count himself is by no means exempt— At my own house, and in the presence of my own family, only, I did not think it proper to discuss the subject with the Count, or to touch him in his tender parts, as the champion of the Merchants— When he charged the merchants with being the Causes of the present War, I asked him only, why he did not allow its share to the island of Malta? The Count has a Commanderie, in the old order of Malta; and I knew it would give a different direction to the chain of his ideas. He did not at first understand me; for he had forgotten that the War began upon a question about Malta— But when reminded of it, he talked about the wisdom of Charles the 5th: in giving the island of Malta, to the Order, so that it might be possessed by no territorial power; because small as it was, whatever territorial power should possess it must have the command of the Mediterranean— I finished the Evening, about 11 O’Clock, immediately after the Count went away.

16. Rose about 6 this Morning— Read, wrote and walked before Breakfast— Much of the day was employed in settling my monthly Bills. I received from Count Soltikoff a large packet, which came from Paris by the way of Wilna— It contained three packets from the Department of State— One of Congressional Documents— One of Newspapers, and one, with two letters 22. and 25. Feby: from the Secy: of State Mr Monroe— One of them I was two hours at least in reading— Walked after dinner in the Summer Gardens, and then was engaged untill nearly one in the morning with the Newspapers from America.

17. A late Evening as usual made a late morning. But late hours are in this Country of such universal practice that I have not yet been able for myself to break through it with any regularity. The state of my health however and the decay of years which I begin to feel advancing very sensibly upon me, warn me to persevere in this design. Its execution is the only means of acquiring time for useful occupation.— A late morning deprives me almost entirely of the day— I walked however before dinner— And rode after dinner with the Ladies and Children to Catherinenhoff— On returning, I walked again from the St: Michael’s Palace, through the Summer Garden home— We had a visit from the Chevalier Bezerra and his Lady— I succeeded again in terminating the Evening before 11— I read the Sermons 13. 14. and 15. Vol 6 of the English Preacher. 13. by Leed—on the duty of progressive improvement—by Leed—an excellent Discourse, but less striking to me than the two others by the same author in Vol 5.— 14. Search for Happiness—by Dr S. Clarke—on Psalms IV.6. There be many that say, who will shew us any good?— Lord, lift thou up the light of thy countenance upon us— And I read over again Sterne’s Sermon upon the same text, for the purpose of comparison— The
Doctrine, the general division of the subject, the stress of argument, and the conclusions are precisely the same in both— But Clarke’s is all cool reason, and Sterne’s is all animation— Clarke tells us that Pleasure—Riches and Honours are the ordinary pursuits of Mankind to obtain happiness—that they all terminate in disappointment; and that happiness is to be found only in the enjoyments of Religion— Sterne says the same thing, but he paints the men of pleasure, of wealth and of Ambition—describes their Condition, adventures and disappointments—varies the character of the monied man, modified as the miser or as the man of business, introduces the supplementary character of the philosopher, and concludes by an apt exemplification of his doctrine, in the person of Solomon, and a string quotation from him in the Ecclesiastes. Clarke gives a mere penciled sketch, and Sterne a finished picture, full of expression, and glowing with Colours. Perhaps the difference between the two Styles of preaching could not be shewn in a more forcible light than by these two Compositions— The 15th: Sermon is upon Diligence—a sober and rational moral essay, in the cold Style— I likewise read a few pages of Watts’s Logic

18. I rose about six this morning— Read— Wrote my Journal, and walked the round of the Fontanka— This is occupation for four hours; and brought the time for Breakfast— After which, I was three hours employed with Charles— As he learns by rote three languages at once, English, French and German, each of them has an influence upon his pronunciation of the other— I have let the German take its own course, as being that which it will be least important for him to retain; and that in which I am myself least qualified to give him instruction— Untill very lately I had confined my attention with him to the French; so that now the English is that which he speaks and understands least of all— I have yet proceeded no further with him than merely reading; which will require yet some Months of unabating perseverance— I devote to him at least three hours every day.— Mr Sparrow from Cronstadt called upon me to explain some of the Circumstances respecting the American Sailors who have made complaints to me— After dinner I walked with Charles on the Boulevard, and over the Bridge, which was yesterday replaced— Madame Colombi, her Sister Miss Bode, and Captain Guedes were here in the Evening at tea and supper.

19. Count Soltikoff sent me again a small packet, brought by a Courier from Paris, through Wilna— It was a letter from Captain Henry, enclosing one from my brother introductory of himself— On leaving the United States it seems Captain Henry intended to come here; but he writes me from Paris that his visit to the North is postponed.— I had a visit from Mr Montreal—and walked before Breakfast and after dinner.— I took in the Evening walk Charles with me; and we went to the Summer Garden. The walk for him was rather too long.

20. We had received printed invitations, from General Betancourt, to attend the annual exhibition of the students at the Institute of Ways and Communications, or in other words the school of Engineers, this day and to-morrow from 10. A.M. to 2 P.M. and between ten and eleven this morning I went with Mr Smith— The examination was confined altogether to the mathematical Sciences—Arithmetic—Algebra—Theory of Proportions and Progressions; with the Construction of Logarithms, and the use of the Tables—Elementary Geometry—Plain Trigonometry and the use of the tables of sines— And explanations of the instruments used in surveying— The Students appeared to be from about fourteen to nineteen or twenty years of age, and the examination was a real and rigorous one— The problems given them for solution were entirely unexpected to them, and for which they could have no previous preparation— Some of them, which required long and complicated demonstrations, were proposed by strangers present, and not by their own teachers— They acquitted themselves of the demonstrations apparently with readiness and facility; with very little assistance from the teachers, and with as much correctness as could be expected from them as Masters of their subjects upon sudden, unpremeditated calls— I said apparently, because the greatest part of the examination was beyond my own reach in Mathematics; and I could not pursue their demonstrations so fast as they carried them through— There was a Collation as usual after the exhibition— On returning home I found English and French Newspapers which occupied the remainder of the day. I took a long walk after dinner, and observed the setting of the Sun, at the stand upon the Quay of the Neva, opposite the Winter Palace.

21. I attended alone this morning, at the second day’s examination at the school of Engineers— The eldest scholars were examined—young men of nineteen or twenty, who I presume are prepared to quit the Institution— They were examined in the highest parts of the mathematics— The Conic Sections, infinite series, and fluxions— They were generally ready, and quick in their solutions, but there was one instance of a failure, and several of some embarrassment in the procedure. The principal examiners were four French Officers, who have been engaged for this school, but who are now obliged to return to France. The whole Institution is under the direction of General Betancourt a Spanish Officer, who has been only about three years in the Russian service.— There were only
four or five of the young Men examined, and it finished before two O’Clock.— Mr Bezerra was the only foreign Minister who attended, besides myself, and he was not there more than half an hour— We did not partake of the Collation; but went and looked over the designs and drawings and plans of the young men, which were in another Hall.— They appeared to be all well executed, but the name of the professor was annexed to each of the designs, as well as of the pupil who executed it. Mr Thomond the Architect is one of the professors, and all the designs of Architecture appeared to be his— The House where this school is kept was purchased of Prince Yussupoff, and is a magnificent building, with a large and elegant Garden— The Hall where the examination was held is spacious and is constructed for a large library— The book-cases are built all round the sides of the walls, and a gallery about 8 or 9 feet from the floor and extending round three sides of the Hall gives the advantages of two Stories in one Room— The Several Apartments are lettered at the top Alphabetically, and according to an order of Sciences. The theoretical order and arrangement of the Hall is ingenious and convenient for a library— But there are scarcely any books— The Cases are almost all empty— One of the doors opening to the next Hall is painted in imitation of Books— So that the whole Hall seems an emblem of promise without performance, and the imposture of learning— For such an Institution where the instruction seems exclusively confined to the Mathematics, a large library cannot be necessary— But Prince Yussupoff to whom the house belonged has a very voluminous library himself, which I suppose he kept in this Hall, and it has been left unaltered, since the purchase of the house— There is an immense expenditure upon this school, but like all the other foundations for Education here it is carried on by the means only of foreign teachers— Of nine or ten Professors who conducted this examination, one only appeared to be a Russian; and he was so continually interfering, and intermeddling with the demonstrations of the pupils, sometimes to help them when they did not want help, and sometimes disconcerting instead of aiding them, that General Betancourt, after repeatedly manifesting by looks and gestures his impatience and dissatisfaction, at last peremptorily ordered the professor to let the young men alone, to do their own work— I returned home and read untill dinner time— In my Evening walk I met and walked an hour with Mr Krabbe— We finished at home the Evening with Cards— There was this morning a flight of Snow, for two or three hours. The month of May scarcely ever passes here without it.

22. Mrs Adams and myself had an invitation from Count St: Julien to dinner this day but sent an excuse. I received a note from Mr Brandel mentioning that there would be an opportunity to send to Stockholm to-morrow morning, by which I could if I wished, write to Baron Engeström. I accordingly wrote, and in the Evening carried and delivered the letter to him— At the same time I paid a visit to Count Löwenhielm, who presented to me his nephew of the same name, who lately came as a Courier, and I suppose returns as such— The Count appears still unsatisfied with this Government and particularly with the Chancellor— He holds the War as inevitable, and thinks the state of France almost desperate— France he says, powerful as she seems will be fighting for her existence— He thinks an immediate Peace between Turkey and Russia very probable— He says he has been four years in Turkey, and knows them well— That money, and boy-favourites can do any thing with them.— I want more data to form a decisive opinion of the Count’s Judgment. Some of his opinions appear to me not very judicious— [symbols]

23. I had a new application from an English Sailor, who came in the Philadelphia Packet—a Vessel seized last Summer for coming under false American Papers— He brought me letters from five others who call themselves Americans; but say they have lost their protections— I sent him to Mr Harris— I dined at the Chevalier Bezerra’s— Mr Koscheleff—the Duke de Serra Capriola and his Son, Count Löwenhielm and Mr Brandel, and Sir Robert Ker Porter were there— The party was politically all English;—myself excepted, though Sir Robert was the only real Englishman there— Mr Koscheleff was the most loudly so of all the Company— General Betancourt was also there— I enquired of him what mathematical elementary books were used at the Institution— He said La Croix’s complete Course— Which he had had reprinted here, because the Paris Edition was too dear for the Students— It is in eight Volumes, only four of which have yet been reprinted— He promised me to let me have a set of the Volumes already printed. I came home early, and rode with the Ladies and Charles to Catherinenhoff. It was my only exercise for the day.

24. Walking on the Quay of the Neva before dinner, I met Count Löwenhielm, who promised to send me a new Proclamation of the British Government respecting the Orders in Council, which he had received by a Russian Courier arrived last Night from Oerabro where the Swedish Diet is now assembled. He also told me that a new Proposition for Peace had been made by France to England which had been rejected, and that he considered the War between Russia and France as more certain than ever.— I asked him if he had any particular news from the Diet— Oui—tout va bien— From Paris?— The Swedish Chargé d’Affairs had been prevailed upon by the Duke de Bassano, not to present the Note, from Sweden—but had sent back the Courier with some unsatisfactory answer
His conduct had been highly disapproved in Sweden, and the note had been sent back to him with peremptory orders to present it— In Spain, Badajos was taken by the English— The Siege of Cadix raised— Ballasteros at Seville, and Joseph retiring into France.— Napoleon was doing every thing in his power to avoid a War; but it was now too late. . . After dinner I sent to the Count’s lodgings for the Proclamation, which he sent me— It is in French, and refers particularly to the United States, but appears intended really to cajole Sweden— I returned it to him this Evening, as he requested— Rode to the Summer-Gardens, and walked in both of them with Charles— We met and walked with Captain Boit— On returning home I found Mr Fisher and Mr Ingraham— Mr Harris afterwards paid us a visit.— I wrote to Mr Gray this day; and read Sermons 1. and 2. Vol. 7. of the English Preacher—the first by Tillotson, on the proportion of religious duty to knowledge—and the second by Foster, on the natural progress of Vice, and the true guard of Innocence; exemplified in the conduct of St Peter, and his denial of his Lord. I distinguish this as one of the best Sermons in the Collection— I read in the Bible this morning 1 Chronicles XXII.14. that David said to Solomon, “Now, behold, in my trouble, I have prepared for the house of the Lord an hundred thousand talents of Gold, and a thousand thousand talents of silver[”] &c—now according to the value fixed in my Bible the talent of Gold was equal to 24261 dollars 40 Cents and the Talent of Silver to 1516 dollars 26 Cents 8 Mills. by this Estimate the gold and silver said by David to have been prepared by him in his trouble was no less than three thousand nine hundred forty two millions, four hundred and eight thousand dollars—more than the whole present National debt of Great-Britain— David may have spoken figuratively; meaning only to say a very large sum—but this is a weak conjecture— The Estimate of the Talents may be incorrect—more probably.— The numbers in the manuscripts may be inaccurate—which is most likely— But either or all these suppositions is more credible than that David should have collected such masses of silver and gold to be expended upon one house— From the enumeration of the People made about the same time, the population of the twelve tribes appears to have amounted to about seven millions and a half, and certainly could not exceed eight millions

25 A Snow-storm, which continued the whole day confined me to the house untill the Evening, when I walked to the Summer-Garden, though it had not then altogether abated— It snowed with little intermission the whole day; but as the snow melted as it fell the streets and roofs of the houses were only powdered, without forming a bed of Snow— I received from Gothenburg letters from my father and mother, forwarded by Mr Hall who was here last year.

26. Having had this day no interruption, of any kind I employed it, as my intention would be to employ every day— My reading and writing before breakfast, together with a lesson to Charles occupied the whole time— A letter to the Secretary of State, another lesson to Charles and a walk of an hour, as fully occupied it untill the hour of dinner— The American Papers and a second walk of an hour and a half engaged the Evening untill past nine— An hour and a half past with the family, finished the day and Evening at eleven I was in bed.— If I could give to my own Amusement and Instruction the part of the day which I give to teach Charles his letters, I should be well satisfied with this distribution of my time— If I had my other boys with me it would be impossible for me to officiate as the school-master of all three— And I probably might employ my hours in a manner of more extensive usefulness than in teaching boys the first elements of learning— As however this teaching of my own children is a humour of my own I shall continue to indulge it as long as I can; praying for the blessing of Heaven upon it.

27. It was my intention to have employed this day as yesterday— But Charles came before Breakfast, wishing for a walk and I went round by the English Quay with him— After Breakfast I had a visit from Mr Montreal, and Mr Harris sent me a file of English Morning Chronicles, for ten days— After dinner I received the Journal de l’Empire and Hamburg Gazette, containing the President’s Message to Congress, and several of the Documents communicated by Captain Henry to the American Government— I walked again in the Evening and met the French Ambassador, who told me that he was waiting orders for his departure. The part of my purposed occupation that suffered was the writing— I barely began a letter for America— I met Mr Boucher in my Evening walk, and he requested me to return him his Books, which I promised him I would— I shall not have time to finish Paucton.

28. It was by an exertion that I finished this day the letter yesterday begun— After dinner I called upon Mr Woodward who is confined to his chamber in consequence of a fall from his horse on the day of the Catherinenhoff procession— I returned him some letters concerning Mr Gray’s affairs, which he sent me last Sunday— I afterwards walked untill ten in the Evening.— The days are now so long, that there is no darkness; but the weather continues cold and cheerless— The Season is three weeks less advanced than at this time last year.

29. Walked with Charles this morning before Breakfast— Visit from Mr Montreal— Walking again after dinner I met first Dr Galloway, who was full of news from England, and afterwards the Chevalier Brancia with whom I walked, about half an hour. We also met Count Serge Soltykoff buried in a furr’d and wadded surtout, who thought we were imprudent to be abroad without the same security— Mr and Madame Bezerra paid us an Evening visit, but found none of us at home.

30. Walk with Charles immediately after Breakfast— I called at Mr Fisher’s and found Dr Galloway and others there— Mr Fisher has been some days unwell— At 3. O’Clock afternoon I went and took a warm Bath, at the public Baths— I took Charles with me, but not into the Bath— Walked home, and walked again in the Evening— As soon as the weather becomes warm I propose to renew the cold Baths which I found myself obliged to give up at the beginning of the Winter.

31. Walked with Charles to the Summer Gardens, and over the Bridge; as we were returning we met Mr: or Sir Robert Ker Porter— I had afterwards a morning visit from Count Bussche, who expects every day to receive the order for his departure, and who is under some alarm with regard to the safety of the Journey; particularly for his Children. After dinner I took a ride with the Ladies and Children to Kammenoi-Ostroff, where the trees are putting out their leaves, and the verdure is returning to the fields.— We saw the Piles of the Bridge that General Betancourt is building from the Apothecary’s Island to Kammenoi Ostroff— It is the first permanent Bridge over any of the Branches of the Neva at this City— As we returned, I left the Carriage when we came to the Summer Garden, walked a turn in it; and thence home. I met on the Boulevards the Chevalier Brancia, and walked one round with him— Early to-bed— I read this day in the English Preacher Vol. 7. the Sermons 3 and 4. On Humility.— Plain and Sensible Discourses, on a Subject of importance, but concerning which my mind is not settled to its own satisfaction— Humility, as this preacher Remarks is a mediate Virtue, between the excesses of Pride, and Pusillanimity. He also well observes, that although between those two Vices and perfectly distinct from them both, it resembles the latter more than the former, and that the former is the more general and predominating vice than the latter— He expatiates well upon the nature of Humility— Its excellence as a Christian Virtue; and the duty and proper means of cultivating it.— But the great difficulty with regard to all these intermediate moral Qualities, is in applying the principle to the practice of Life. I cherish the Virtue of Humility, in proportion to the scarcity of it in the world— When associated with active and energetic powers, it is truly admirable— But there is great danger in that Humility, which implies the sacrifice of one’s own Judgment to the opinions and wishes of others— In all the relations of Life, public and private, I have found this difficulty constantly recurring, and when compelled to decide, have erred sometimes in following the dictates of my own mind, and sometimes in yielding to the persuasions of others. The only true reliance is from above.

Day. Differs from that of the last Month only by the difference of the Season.— I am still endeavouring to establish the practice of early retirement at night, and early rising in the Morning— I find it becoming more and more indispensable to my health, as age is creeping with insensible stealth upon me— Orderly and regular hours are becoming objects to me of the first necessity. I do not yet however find it practicable yet to accomplish my intentions entirely— The time that I allow for Charles’s instruction increases— Taking the whole result from the time when we came into the City last Autumn untill now, and his progress in reading French has been considerable— It is now more than a month since I began with him the reading of English— I can scarcely say that he has made any progress in that— Sometimes for a week or ten days together he seems to fall back instead of advancing—listlessness, languor, inapplication, weariness and disgust at the pain of learning, with all this a teacher must be patient and all this he must overcome by perseverance— There is not unfrequently too in Charles, and I observed it before in George, a sort of perverseness which relucts at amendment— He often persists in reading or pronouncing words wrong, when he knows perfectly well the right— This is the severest trial of temper— The only way that I find effectual for keeping my good homour, is by reflecting how much of the same indolence, inapplication and indocility, I had, and still have in myself. Another encouragement and consolation is the thought of a result which has been obtained.— He reads a lesson of two pages in Dufief’s Conversations, and one in Berquin of six eight or ten pages, every day— The exceptions this month have been, if any, certainly not more than two or three— He begins to understand some parts of what he reads, and discovers symptoms of taking some interest in it— This afternoon of his own accord he asked to continue a scene in Berquin.
